data.title: Gus Grissom and the Tale of the Lost Liberty Bell
data.meta_description: How the story of astronaut Gus Grissom's Liberty Bell 7 mission became enshrouded in myth, and how Grissom's early death contributed.
data.text:
(Author’s note: at one point I was supposed to write a book about space myths, but never got around to finishing it due to other professional obligations. This was the Chapter One draft, originally finished in 2018. This piece is an extended version of this blog post, published in 2016. Enjoy.)

In the sixties NASA set out to fashion its image, but the myth of the super-hero astronaut was purely a creation of the news media. Most of us found it flattering and easy to go along with. Some even cultivated that image, but few could measure up to it. Most of us recognized it was unlivable only slightly before we realized we were stuck with it for the rest of our lives. We will remain in that image until the public takes off its rose-colored glasses and begins to see us as people. — Astronaut Walt Cunningham

The second and last suborbital Mercury spaceflight started just like every spaceflight as Mercury-Redstone MRLV 8 cleared Launch Complex 5 at Florida’s Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on a sweltering summer’s morning, July 21, 1961 — with an announcement of “liftoff,” and a rumble and shudder of engine fire.
